trans-unit.source: Get Started with Mobile Services for Windows Store apps | Mobile Dev Center
trans-unit.target: Get Started with Mobile Services for Windows Store apps | Mobile Dev Center

trans-unit.source: Follow this tutorial to get started using Azure Mobile Services for Windows Store development in C#, VB, or JavaScript.
trans-unit.target: Follow this tutorial to get started using Azure Mobile Services for Windows Store development in C#, VB, or JavaScript.

trans-unit.source: Get started with Mobile Services
trans-unit.target: Get started with Mobile Services

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: This tutorial shows you how to add a cloud-based backend service to a universal Windows app using Azure Mobile Services.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial shows you how to add a cloud-based backend service to a universal Windows app using Azure Mobile Services.

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you will create both a new mobile service and a simple *To do list* app in HTML and JavaScript that stores app data in the new mobile service.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you will create both a new mobile service and a simple *To do list* app in HTML and JavaScript that stores app data in the new mobile service.

trans-unit.source: The mobile service that you create uses the supported .NET languages using Visual Studio for server-side business logic and to manage the mobile service.
trans-unit.target: The mobile service that you create uses the supported .NET languages using Visual Studio for server-side business logic and to manage the mobile service.

trans-unit.source: To create a mobile service that lets you write your server-side business logic in JavaScript, see the JavaScript version of this topic.
trans-unit.target: To create a mobile service that lets you write your server-side business logic in JavaScript, see the JavaScript version of this topic.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: To complete this tutorial, you need the following:
trans-unit.target: To complete this tutorial, you need the following:

trans-unit.source: An active Azure account.
trans-unit.target: An active Azure account.

trans-unit.source: If you don't have an account, you can create a free trial account in just a couple of minutes.
trans-unit.target: If you don't have an account, you can create a free trial account in just a couple of minutes.

trans-unit.source: For details, see [Azure Free Trial](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/free-trial/?WT.mc_id=A0E0E5C02&returnurl=http%3A%2F%2Fazure.microsoft.com%2Fen-us%2Fdocumentation%2Farticles%2Fmobile-services-javascript-backend-windows-store-javascript-get-started%2F).
trans-unit.target: For details, see [Azure Free Trial](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/free-trial/?WT.mc_id=A0E0E5C02&returnurl=http%3A%2F%2Fazure.microsoft.com%2Fen-us%2Fdocumentation%2Farticles%2Fmobile-services-javascript-backend-windows-store-javascript-get-started%2F).

trans-unit.source: Visual Studio Professional 2013.
trans-unit.target: Visual Studio Professional 2013.

trans-unit.source: A free trial version is available.
trans-unit.target: A free trial version is available.

trans-unit.source: Create a new mobile service
trans-unit.target: Create a new mobile service

trans-unit.source: Create a new universal Windows app
trans-unit.target: Create a new universal Windows app

trans-unit.source: Once you have created your mobile service, you can follow an easy quickstart in the Management Portal to either create a new app or modify an existing app to connect to your mobile service.
trans-unit.target: Once you have created your mobile service, you can follow an easy quickstart in the Management Portal to either create a new app or modify an existing app to connect to your mobile service.

trans-unit.source: In this section you will create a new universal Windows app that is connected to your mobile service.
trans-unit.target: In this section you will create a new universal Windows app that is connected to your mobile service.

trans-unit.source: In the Management Portal, click **Mobile Services**, and then click the mobile service that you just created.
trans-unit.target: In the Management Portal, click **Mobile Services**, and then click the mobile service that you just created.

trans-unit.source: In the quickstart tab, click **Windows** under **Choose platform** and expand **Create a new Windows Store app**.
trans-unit.target: In the quickstart tab, click **Windows** under **Choose platform** and expand **Create a new Windows Store app**.

trans-unit.source: This displays the three easy steps to create a Windows Store app connected to your mobile service.
trans-unit.target: This displays the three easy steps to create a Windows Store app connected to your mobile service.

trans-unit.source: If you haven't already done so, download and install Visual Studio Professional 2013 on your local computer or virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: If you haven't already done so, download and install Visual Studio Professional 2013 on your local computer or virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Under **Download and run your app and service locally**, select a language for your Windows Store app, then click **Download**.
trans-unit.target: Under **Download and run your app and service locally**, select a language for your Windows Store app, then click **Download**.

trans-unit.source: This downloads a solution contains projects for both the mobile service and for the sample _To do list_ application that is connected to your mobile service.
trans-unit.target: This downloads a solution contains projects for both the mobile service and for the sample _To do list_ application that is connected to your mobile service.

trans-unit.source: Save the compressed project file to your local computer, and make a note of where you save it.
trans-unit.target: Save the compressed project file to your local computer, and make a note of where you save it.

trans-unit.source: Test the app against the local mobile service
trans-unit.target: Test the app against the local mobile service

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE]You can review the code that accesses your mobile service to query and insert data, which is found in the default.js file.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE]You can review the code that accesses your mobile service to query and insert data, which is found in the default.js file.

trans-unit.source: Publish your mobile service
trans-unit.target: Publish your mobile service

trans-unit.source: 4.
trans-unit.target: 4.

trans-unit.source: In the Shared code project, open the default.js file, locate the code that creates a [WindowsAzure.MobileServiceClient](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/jj554219.aspx) instance, comment-out the code that creates this client using *localhost* and uncomment the code that creates the client using the remote mobile service URL, which looks like the following:
trans-unit.target: In the Shared code project, open the default.js file, locate the code that creates a [WindowsAzure.MobileServiceClient](http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/jj554219.aspx) instance, comment-out the code that creates this client using *localhost* and uncomment the code that creates the client using the remote mobile service URL, which looks like the following:

trans-unit.source: The client will now access the mobile service published to Azure.
trans-unit.target: The client will now access the mobile service published to Azure.

trans-unit.source: 5.
trans-unit.target: 5.

trans-unit.source: Press the **F5** key to rebuild the project and start the app.
trans-unit.target: Press the **F5** key to rebuild the project and start the app.

trans-unit.source: 6.
trans-unit.target: 6.

trans-unit.source: In the app, type meaningful text, such as *Complete the tutorial*, in **Insert a TodoItem**, and then click **Save**.
trans-unit.target: In the app, type meaningful text, such as *Complete the tutorial*, in **Insert a TodoItem**, and then click **Save**.

trans-unit.source: This sends a POST request to the new mobile service hosted in Azure.
trans-unit.target: This sends a POST request to the new mobile service hosted in Azure.

trans-unit.source: 7.
trans-unit.target: 7.

trans-unit.source: (Optional) In a universal Windows solution, change the default start up project to the other app and press **F5** again and notice that data saved from the previous step is loaded from the mobile service after the app starts.
trans-unit.target: (Optional) In a universal Windows solution, change the default start up project to the other app and press **F5** again and notice that data saved from the previous step is loaded from the mobile service after the app starts.

trans-unit.source: For more information about universal Windows apps, see [Supporting multiple device platforms from a single mobile service](mobile-services-how-to-use-multiple-clients-single-service.md#shared-vs).
trans-unit.target: For more information about universal Windows apps, see [Supporting multiple device platforms from a single mobile service](mobile-services-how-to-use-multiple-clients-single-service.md#shared-vs).

trans-unit.source: test
trans-unit.target: test
